Create and run a job

Unity jobs let you schedule small units of work so the main thread can keep rendering and gameplay responsive. A job typically operates on NativeArray data, is scheduled from the main thread, and completed when the results are needed. This fixture intentionally contains enough text to exercise markdown conversion and extraction logic.

Schedule and Complete best practices

Use JobHandle dependencies to chain work, avoid forcing the main thread to wait too early, and call Complete as late as possible when you need job results. This helps maximize parallel throughput and keeps frame time stable.

For data-parallel workloads, use IJobParallelFor with a tuned batch count and avoid oversynchronizing unrelated jobs. Profiling helps determine whether you should split long jobs into smaller dependent jobs.
